frameDefinitions: An Agent displays a Characteristic of a Standard in his or her own way of behaving.

This frame involves a static (primarily spatial) relationship between a Location and a Theme, in which the Theme is located in many or all subregions of the Location, and is thus construable as covering it.
An Agent affects a Patient in such a way that the Patient (or some Subregion of the Patient) ends up in a non-canonical state.
A Cause, animate or inanimate, causes a process, the Effect, to begin.
A Figure is located relative to a Ground location.
frameExamples: I guessed he was trying to <t>imitate</t> the movements of a skier
The hand <t>around</t> the sword-hilt was no less impressive than the sword .
The murder of Sergei Kirov <t>set off</t> a chain of events that culminated in the Great Terror of the 1930s.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person that borrows a <fen>Characteristic</fen> behavior from a <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Characteristic</fen> is a behavior or property that the <fen>Standard</fen> possesses and which the <fen>Agent</fen> adopts in his or her own behavior.
The <fen>Standard</fen> is the entity that exhibits a certain <fen>Characteristic</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> models their own behavior on.
The time at which the imitation occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> imitates some entity which acts as a <fen>Standard</fen>.

The <fen>Theme</fen> in this frame is the object which is described as standing in some spatial relation to a particular <fen>Location</fen>.  <fen>Theme</fen> typically occurs as the External Argument or, with passives, as a PP Complement headed by 'with' or 'by'.
<fen>Location</fen> is the entity or area with respect to which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s spatial arrangement is described.  This frame element generally occurs as an NP Object.
The time at which the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies the <fen>Location</fen>.
The conscious entity, generally a person, that performs the intentional action that results in the damage to the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The entity which is affected by the <fen>Agent</fen> so that it is damaged.
An event which leads to the damage of the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> damages the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the location of the scene where a <fen>Agent</fen> damages a <fen>Patient</fen>.
The <fen>Figure</fen> is the entity located with respect to the <fen>Ground</fen>.
The <fen>Ground</fen> is the area that the <fen>Figure</fen> surrounds.
The area or zone immediately external to the <fen>Ground</fen>.  This role excludes <fen>Figure</fen> and is only used in particular constructions such as the following:
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Figure</fen> is located around the <fen>Ground</fen>.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces an effect. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of <fen>Cause</fen>s.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate the process that the <fen>Cause</fen> initiates.
This role is for the <fen>Time</fen>  when causing to start occurs
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Effect</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
The <fen>Figures</fen> are items which mutually serve to identify the location of the other items.
The region within which a <fen>Figure</fen> might be found.  This role is exclusive of <fen>Figure</fen>, and is a reconstrual that is not possible with verb lexical units.
The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
listRoleExamples: Mimic Snotlings do n't really think for themselves, <fex>they</fex> merely mimic the actions of Orcs and Goblins around them.
The singer says Gwen has copied <fex>her</fex> in many different ways.
<fex>The crash</fex> dented my car pretty bad.
He had <fex>both hands</fex> wrapped around her arm .
Few things spark <fex>the wrath of the British</fex> like food additives.
<fex>In Obscurania</fex>, the release of the movie sparked protests.
<fex><t>Next to</t> the kitchen</fex> is the best place to locate your garage .

sourceCandidateSpans.text: a bright July day 2 years ago
the University of California, Santa Barbara
the Alfred Wegener Institute for Polar and Marine Research
